phrase.original: a free, portable, powerful photo editor
PhotoDemon is the product of many talented contributors, including
PhotoDemon is released under an open-source BSD license
Please note that PhotoDemon uses several third-party plugins
These plugins are also free and open source
...but they are governed by their own licenses, separate from PhotoDemon
For more information on plugin licensing, please visit
Are you sure you want to cancel %1?

Open one or more images for editing.
(Another way to open images is dragging them from your desktop or Windows Explorer and dropping them onto PhotoDemon.)

Close the current image.
If the current image has not been saved, you will receive a prompt to save it before it closes.

Close the current image.
Because you have turned off save prompts (via Edit -> Preferences), you WILL NOT receive a prompt to save this image before it closes.

Save the current image.

There is not enough memory available to continue this operation. Please free up system memory (RAM) and try again. If the problem persists, reduce the zoom value and try again.

Unknown processor request submitted: %1
Please report this bug via the Help -> Submit Bug Report menu.

There is not enough memory available to continue this operation. Please free up system memory (RAM) by shutting down unneeded programs - especially your web browser, if it is open - then try the action again.

Unfortunately, this image file appears to be invalid. This can happen if a file does not contain image data, or if it contains image data in an unsupported format.
- If you downloaded this image from the Internet, the download may have terminated prematurely. Please try downloading the image again.
- If this image file came from a digital camera, scanner, or other image editing program, it's possible that PhotoDemon simply doesn't understand this particular file format. Please save the image in a generic format (such as JPEG or PNG), then reload it.

The specified file could not be located. If it was located on removable media, please re-insert the proper floppy disk, CD, or portable drive. If the file is not located on portable media, make sure that: 1) the file hasn't been deleted, and... 2) the file location provided to PhotoDemon is correct.

PhotoDemon cannot locate additional information for this error. That probably means this error is a bug, and it needs to be fixed!
Would you like to submit a bug report? (It takes less than one minute, and it helps everyone who uses the software.)

PhotoDemon has experienced an error. Details on the problem include:
Error number %1 Description: %2
%3

Thank you for submitting a bug report. To make sure your bug is addressed as quickly as possible, PhotoDemon needs you to answer one more question.
Do you have a GitHub account? (If you have no idea what this means, answer "No".)

PhotoDemon has automatically opened a GitHub bug report webpage for you. In the Title box, please enter the following error number with a short description of the problem: %1
Any additional details you can provide in the large text box, including the steps that led up to this error, will help it get fixed as quickly as possible.
When finished, click the Submit New Issue button. Thank you!

PhotoDemon has automatically opened a bug report webpage for you. In the Additional Details box, please describe the steps that led to this error.
In the bottom box of that page, please enter the following error number: %1
When finished, click the Submit button. Thank you!

This menu item only appears in the Visual Basic IDE.
You can use the MenuTest() sub in the Filters_Miscellaneous module to test your own filters. I typically do this first, then once the filter is working properly, I give it a subroutine of its own.

NOTE: Some options on this page have been disabled because the FreeImage plugin is missing. To enable these options, please click on "Updates" and select "if core plugins cannot be located, offer to download them." Then restart the program and select "Yes" when prompted.
NOTE: Many of these file format options require the FreeImage plugin. Because you do not have the FreeImage plugin installed, these options may not perform as expected.
max PhotoDemon memory usage this session
Interface options include settings for the main PhotoDemon interface, including things like canvas settings, font selection, and positioning.
Load options allow you to customize the way image files enter the application.
Save options allow you to customize the way image files leave the application.
File format options control how PhotoDemon handles certain types of images.
Tool options currently include customizable options for the Selection Tool. In the future, PhotoDemon will gain paint tools, and those settings will appear here as well.
Transparency options control how PhotoDemon displays images that contain alpha channels (e.g. 32bpp images).
Update options control how frequently PhotoDemon checks for updated versions, and how it handles the download of missing plugins.
Advanced options can be safely ignored by regular users. Testers and developers may, however, find these settings useful.

PhotoDemon provides two non-essential features that require Internet access: checking for software updates, and offering to download core plugins (FreeImage, EZTwain, zLib, and pngnq-s9) if they aren't present in the \Data\Plugins subdirectory.
The developers of PhotoDemon take privacy very seriously, so no information - statistical or otherwise - is uploaded by these features. Checking for software updates involves downloading a single "updates.txt" file containing the latest software version number. Similarly, downloading missing plugins simply involves downloading one or more of the compressed plugin files from the PhotoDemon server.
If you choose to disable these features, note that you can always visit tannerhelland.com/photodemon to manually download the most recent version of the program.

While multitasking, some find it convenient to have the PhotoDemon task bar icon reflect the image currently being edited. This option allows PhotoDemon to automatically update the task bar and window icons as necessary.
The "Recent Files" menu width is limited by Windows. To prevent this menu from overflowing, PhotoDemon can display image names only instead of full image locations.

When checked, this option allows PhotoDemon to automatically remove empty alpha channels from imported images. This improves program performance, reduces RAM usage, and improves file size on exported files.
Bitmap files only support one type of compression, and they only support it for certain color depths. PhotoDemon can apply simple RLE compression when saving 8bpp images.
TGA files only support one type of compression. PhotoDemon can apply simple RLE compression when saving TGA images.
TIFFs support both RGB and CMYK color spaces. RGB is used by default, but if a TIFF file is going to be used in printed document, CMYK is sometimes required.
TIFFs support a variety of compression techniques. Some of these techniques are limited to specific color depths, so make sure you pick one that matches the images you plan on saving.
PNG interlacing is similar to "progressive scan" on JPEGs. Interlacing slightly increases file size, but an interlaced image can "fade-in" while it downloads.
PNG files can contain a background color parameter. This takes up extra space in the file, so feel free to disable it if you don't need background colors.
Binary encoding of PPM files is strongly suggested. (In other words, don't change this setting unless you are certain that ASCII encoding is what you want. :)

This option allows PhotoDemon to scan incoming images to determine the most appropriate color depth on a case-by-case basis (rather than relying on the source image file's color depth, which may have been chosen arbitrarily).
Tone mapping is used to preserve the tonal range of HDR images. This setting is very useful for RAW photos and scanned documents, but it adds a significant amount of time to the image load process.

When the "Crop to Selection" command is used, the resulting image will always contain a selection the same size as the full image. There is generally no need to retain this, so PhotoDemon can automatically clear it for you.

If this is checked, PhotoDemon will create a human-readable .log file that contains the text of every message displayed on the progress bar. This will increase processing time, so only check this option if you really need debugging data.
PhotoDemon relies on three open-source plugins for full functionality. If they are missing, this will allow the software to automatically download them.
Some image file types support a variety of color depths. PhotoDemon's developers suggest letting the software choose the best color depth for you, unless you have reason to choose otherwise.

In most photo editors, the "Save" command saves the image over its original version, erasing that copy forever. PhotoDemon provides a "safer" option, where each save results in a new copy of the file.

Most photo editors use the format of the current image as the default in the "Save As" screen. When working with RAW images that will eventually be saved to JPEG, it is useful to have PhotoDemon remember that - hence the "last used" option.
Some image formats can hold multiple images in one file. When these files are encountered, PhotoDemon can ignore the extra images, or it can load them all for you.
Any photo larger than 2 megapixels is too big to fit on an average computer monitor. PhotoDemon can automatically zoom out on large photographs so that the entire image is viewable.
The image canvas sits "behind" the image on the screen. Dark colors are generally preferable, as they help the image stand out while you work on it.
If an image has transparent areas, a checkerboard is typically displayed "behind" the image. This box lets you change the checkerboard's colors.
If an image has transparent areas, a checkerboard is typically displayed "behind" the image. This box lets you change the checkerboard's size.
Some image file types support additional parameters when importing and exporting. By default, PhotoDemon will manage these for you, but you can specify different parameters if necessary.
Click to change the image window background color
Click to change the first checkerboard background color for alpha channels
Click to change the second checkerboard background color for alpha channels

Image metadata is extra data placed in an image file by a camera or photo software. This data can include things like the make and model of the camera, or the GPS coordinates of the photo's location, or many other items. To view an image's metadata, use the Image -> Metadata menu.
WARNING: this folder is invalid (access prohibited). Please provide a valid folder. If no new folder is provided, PhotoDemon will use the system's default temp location.
Image is all one color. Autocrop unnecessary.
Image is already cropped intelligently. Autocrop abandoned. (No changes were made to the image.)

Unfortunately, %1 is preventing %2 from directly downloading this image. (Direct downloads are sometimes mistaken as hotlinking by misconfigured servers.)
You will need to download this image using your Internet browser of choice, then manually load it into %2.
I sincerely apologize for this inconvenience, but unfortunately there is nothing %2 can do about stingy server configurations. :(

This is the recommended selection. PhotoDemon will automatically download the selected plugins for you. These plugins will be saved in the program's /Data/Plugins subdirectory.
This option is not recommended. PhotoDemon will still run without plugins, but many features and tools will be temporarily disabled until these plugins are available.
This option is not recommended. PhotoDemon will still run without plugins, but many features and tools will be permanently disabled.

Load each frame as a separate image
This option will load every frame in the animated GIF file as an individual image.
This option will only load a single frame from the animated GIF file, effectively treating at as a non-animated GIF file.
%1 contains multiple icons (%2 in total). How would you like to proceed?
Load each icon as a separate image
This option will load every icon in the ICO file as an individual image.
This option will only load a single icon from the ICO file.
Load each page as a separate image
This option will load every page in the TIFF file as an individual image.
This option will only load a single page from the TIFF file.
Subsampling affects the way the JPEG encoder compresses image luminance. 4:2:0 (moderate) is the default value.
Waiting for user to specify JPEG export options
advanced settings require the FreeImage plugin
Optimization is highly recommended. This option allows the JPEG encoder to compute an optimal Huffman coding table for the file. It does not affect image quality - only file size.
Embedded thumbnails increase file size, but they help previews of the image appear more quickly in other software (e.g. Windows Explorer).

Progressive encoding is sometimes used for JPEG files that will be used on the Internet. It saves the image in three steps, which can be used to gradually fade-in the image on a slow Internet connection.
Super compression, very poor image quality (256:1)
Waiting for user to specify JPEG-2000 export options
please choose an output color depth
Waiting for user to specify color depth

You are running PhotoDemon inside the Visual Basic IDE. This is not recommended.

Please compile PhotoDemon before using it. Many features that rely on subclassing are disabled in the IDE, but some - such as custom command buttons - cannot be disabled without severely impacting the program's functionality. As such, you may experience IDE instability and crashes, especially if you close the program using the IDE's Stop button.
Additionally, like all other photo editors, PhotoDemon relies heavily on multidimensional arrays. Array performance is severely degraded in the IDE, so some functions may perform very slowly.
If you insist on running PhotoDemon in the IDE, please do not submit bugs regarding IDE crashes or freezes. PhotoDemon's developers can only address issues and bugs that affect the compiled .exe.
Use this to reset all plugin-related options to their default state. This action cannot be undone.

You can add files to the batch process list in several ways
Step 1: prepare the batch list (the list of images to be processed)

If you exit now, your batch list (the list of images to be processed) will be lost. By saving your list, you can easily resume this batch operation at a later date.
Would you like to save your batch list before exiting?
This is not a valid list of images. Please try a different file.
You have already created a list of images for processing. The list of images inside this file will be appended to the bottom of your current list.
You have requested that a macro be applied to each image, but no macro file has been selected. Please select a valid macro file.
PhotoDemon cannot access the requested output folder. Please select a non-system, unrestricted folder for the batch process.
You can add files to the batch list in several ways

1) The folder and file lists at the top of this page. Use the "Add selected image(s) to batch list" button to move images to the batch list, or use the right mouse button to drag-and-drop one or more items.
2) The "Add images using Open Image dialog..." button. You can then select one or more image files to be processed.
3) Drag-and-drop files directly onto the batch list from Windows Explorer or your desktop.
Each of these methods supports use of the Ctrl and Shift keys to select multiple files at once.
Step 2: select the photo editing action(s) to apply to each image
If requested, PhotoDemon can apply a recorded set of actions (a "macro") to each image in the batch list.
Macros can be recorded using the "Tools -> Macros -> Record new macro" menu in the main PhotoDemon window.
(FYI: the next version of PhotoDemon will add a selection of standard photo editing options to this screen, but at present you are limited to macros for any photo editing actions.)
Step 3: choose a destination image format
PhotoDemon needs to know which format to use when saving the images in your batch list.

If "keep images in their original format" is selected, PhotoDemon will attempt to save each image in its current format. However, some esoteric formats may not be supported. If such images are encountered, a standard format (JPEG or PNG, depending on color depth) will be used instead.

If you choose to save these images to a new format, please make sure the format you have selected is appropriate for all images in your list. (For example, images with transparency need to be saved to a format that supports transparency!)
Step 4: provide a destination folder and any renaming options
In this final step, PhotoDemon needs to know where to save the processed images, and what name to give the new files.
For your convenience, a number of standard renaming options are also provided. Note that all options under "additional rename options" are optional.

Finally, if two or more images in the batch list have the same filename, and the "original filenames" option is selected, such files will automatically be given unique filenames upon saving (e.g. "original-filename (2)").
You haven't selected any image files. Please add one or more files to the batch list before saving.

GIF images only support simple transparency, meaning each pixel in a GIF image must be fully transparent or fully opaque. If your batch list includes 32bpp images with complex alpha channels, PhotoDemon must simplify them before saving to GIF format.
By default, transparency will be split down the middle, or you can specify a custom cut-off value.
if PhotoDemon does not support an image's original format, a standard format will be used
( specifically, JPEG at 92% quality for photographs, and lossless PNG for non-photographs )
